metadata.description: Comprehensive college admissions knowledge base with university-specific criteria, counselor perspectives, and evaluation frameworks

universal_themes.holistic_review: No school admits on academics alone. Every top university uses holistic review that considers academics, activities, essays, recommendations, and context together.
universal_themes.depth_over_breadth: Passion and impact in focused areas beats being well-rounded. Admissions officers prefer students who show genuine mastery and commitment in 2-3 areas over shallow involvement in 10+ activities.
universal_themes.authentic_voice: Essays must reflect genuine student perspective. Over-edited essays that sound like parents or consultants wrote them are easily detected and work against applicants.
universal_themes.context_matters: Evaluations consider opportunities available to the student. First-generation, low-income, and students from under-resourced schools are evaluated in context.
universal_themes.mission_alignment: Schools seek students who fit their specific culture. MIT wants makers; Harvard wants leaders; Chicago wants intellectuals.

highly_selective.note: At highly selective schools, academics are a baseline filter. Extracurriculars and essays differentiate candidates.

university_of_chicago.note: UChicago is famous for unique essay prompts that heavily influence admission decisions.

harvard.name: Harvard University

academic_expectations.course_rigor: Most rigorous available - AP, IB, or advanced coursework expected

what_they_seek: Leadership and distinction in chosen pursuits
Personal qualities: maturity, character, leadership, self-confidence
Potential to contribute to Harvard and society
harvard.evaluation_philosophy: Applications are discussed after initial review and competitive applicants advance to committee, where 40-member committee makes final decisions. No formula for gaining admission.
common_pitfalls: Being 'just' a well-rounded student with good scores
Lacking clear passion or specialization
Generic essays without distinctive personal voice
Activities that look impressive but lack genuine commitment
No clear narrative arc - application feels assembled rather than authentic
harvard.counselor_perspective: Harvard seeks students who have achieved great things in their primary areas of interest. Candidates are most memorable when they have a clear arc to their application: the notable scientist, the future political and community leader, the bridgebuilder. Test scores and grades are baseline filters - they get you into the discussion but don't get you admitted. What distinguishes admits is world-class achievement or clear potential for it.
red_flags: Below 25th percentile scores without compelling context
Essays that sound parent-written or over-polished
Activity list that contradicts stated interests
No demonstrated interest in contributing to community

mit.name: Massachusetts Institute of Technology

academic_expectations.course_rigor: Most rigorous STEM courses available, calculus and physics expected

what_they_seek: Hands-on makers and doers (Mens et Manus - Mind and Hand)
Evidence of building, creating, or making things
Genuine intellectual curiosity and love of learning
Balance - not just STEM robots but well-rounded humans
Resilience and ability to handle rigorous workload
noncognitive_indicators: Curiosity - genuine interest in how things work
Initiative - self-starting, doesn't wait to be told
Ability to accept feedback and iterate
mit.evaluation_philosophy: Every application is read by at least 12 people through the process. Selection committee makes final decisions. Looking for students who will thrive in MIT's collaborative, hands-on environment.

activity_tier_system.tier_2: State-level achievement or founded organization with impact

common_pitfalls: Focusing only on academics without showing what you've built
Presenting as a lone genius rather than collaborative team player
No evidence of hands-on projects or making things
Generic STEM interests without depth
Not showing personality and humor in essays
mit.counselor_perspective: MIT is looking for makers, not just thinkers. They want to see what you've built, created, or done with your hands. The ideal MIT student has a garage full of half-finished projects, not just a perfect transcript. Show them you tinker, experiment, fail, and learn. Collaboration is huge - MIT is not for lone wolves.
red_flags: No evidence of building or making anything
STEM focus without demonstrated hands-on experience
Inability to articulate what drives your curiosity
Activities that show individual achievement but no collaboration

stanford.name: Stanford University
what_they_seek: Intellectual vitality - genuine love of learning and ideas
stanford.essay_philosophy: Essays are weighted very heavily at Stanford. They want to hear YOUR voice - authentic, distinctive, memorable.
common_pitfalls: Generic essays that could apply to any school
Focusing on achievements without showing personality
Not demonstrating intellectual vitality
Activities without clear passion or impact
stanford.counselor_perspective: Stanford cares deeply about authenticity. They can spot a consultant-polished application from miles away. Show them what genuinely excites you intellectually, even if it's quirky or unusual.

yale.name: Yale University
what_they_seek: Strong sense of ethics and character
Genuine interest in ideas and learning
common_pitfalls: STEM-only focus without humanities interests
Not showing how you'll contribute to community
Essays lacking reflection and intellectual depth
yale.counselor_perspective: Yale values the residential college experience. They want students who will engage deeply with each other and with ideas. Show genuine intellectual curiosity and how you'll contribute to campus life.

princeton.name: Princeton University
common_pitfalls: Not understanding Princeton's focus on undergraduate education
Generic 'Why Princeton' essay
Not demonstrating service orientation
princeton.counselor_perspective: Princeton is unusually focused on undergraduates. Show them you understand and value this. Service is huge at Princeton - they want students who will give back.

uchicago.name: University of Chicago
what_they_seek: Love of ideas for their own sake
Willingness to engage with difficult questions
uchicago.essay_philosophy: UChicago's famous 'uncommon' essays are crucial. They want to see how you think, not what you think. Creativity, originality, and genuine intellectual engagement matter most.
common_pitfalls: Playing it safe on the quirky essay prompts
Not showing genuine intellectual curiosity
Taking yourself too seriously
Generic answers to unique prompts
uchicago.counselor_perspective: UChicago wants intellectual weirdos in the best sense. They value students who love ideas, argue about philosophy at lunch, and get genuinely excited about abstract concepts. Show them you're not afraid to be intellectually playful.

ivy_league.what_differentiates: At this level, academics are table stakes. What matters is world-class achievement, distinctive narrative, and genuine fit with the institution.
ivy_league.reality_check: These schools reject 90%+ of applicants. Even perfect stats guarantee nothing.

top_20.what_differentiates: Strong achievement in focus areas, clear passion, authentic essays.

top_50.what_differentiates: Demonstrated interest, good essays, solid activities.

high_priority.name: Well-Rounded But Not Distinguished
high_priority.description: Application shows competence in many areas but no standout achievement or clear identity
detection_signals: Many activities listed (8+) with limited depth in any
No state/national level recognition
Essays don't reveal clear passion or identity
High grades but no academic awards or distinctions
high_priority.counselor_explanation: At highly selective schools, 'well-rounded' is actually a weakness. They're looking for 'well-lopsided' students - those who are exceptional in one or two areas. Your application shows you're good at many things, but it doesn't answer the question: 'Why THIS student over the other 40,000 applicants?'

high_priority.name: No Clear Narrative Arc
high_priority.description: Application feels assembled rather than authentic - pieces don't tell a cohesive story
detection_signals: Activities don't connect to stated interests
Essays don't align with rest of application
No clear thread linking experiences together
Hard to identify what applicant stands for
high_priority.counselor_explanation: The most memorable applicants have a clear story. When admissions officers discuss your file in committee, they need to be able to say 'This is the student who...' Your application makes that difficult. The pieces are there, but they don't form a picture.

high_priority.name: Generic Essays Lacking Authentic Voice
high_priority.description: Essays could have been written by many applicants - nothing distinctive or memorable
detection_signals: Heavy use of clich√©s and common phrases
Could remove student's name and essay could apply to anyone
Sounds more like what admissions wants to hear than genuine voice
Lacks specific, personal details or anecdotes
high_priority.counselor_explanation: Admissions officers read thousands of essays about 'learning from failure' or 'the life-changing trip abroad.' Yours doesn't stand out. What specific moment, detail, or insight could ONLY come from you? That's what's missing.

high_priority.name: Too Many Activities Without Depth
high_priority.description: Long activity list but no evidence of sustained commitment or significant achievement
detection_signals: 8+ activities listed
Most activities are 1-2 years only
Few or no leadership positions
Activities feel like resume padding
high_priority.counselor_explanation: Listing 15 clubs doesn't impress admissions officers - it worries them. They'd rather see 3 activities where you've invested deeply and made real impact than a checklist of surface-level involvements. Quality over quantity, always.

medium_priority.name: Test Scores Below School Average
medium_priority.description: Test scores fall below the typical range for admitted students
detection_signals: SAT/ACT below 25th percentile for target school
No compelling context (first-gen, low-income, etc.)
medium_priority.counselor_explanation: Your test scores are below the typical admitted student range for this school. While scores aren't everything, they are filters. Without a compelling hook or exceptional achievement in other areas, this creates a significant hurdle.

medium_priority.name: Generic 'Why This School' Response
medium_priority.description: The 'Why Us' essay could apply to many schools with minor changes
detection_signals: References to 'prestigious' or 'great programs'
No mention of specific courses, professors, or opportunities
Could copy-paste for another similar school
medium_priority.counselor_explanation: Your 'Why This School' essay doesn't show you've done your homework. Anyone could write 'I want to attend [School] because of its excellent [field] program.' Admissions wants to see specific programs, professors, research opportunities, or campus resources that excite you specifically.

medium_priority.name: Activities Don't Match Stated Interests
medium_priority.description: Claimed interests or intended major aren't supported by activity record
detection_signals: Says 'passionate about CS' but no coding projects
Intends to major in Biology but all activities are in humanities
No connection between activities and stated goals
medium_priority.counselor_explanation: You say you want to major in [field], but your activities don't support that claim. Admissions officers are skeptical when there's a disconnect between what you say and what you've done. They want evidence of genuine interest, not just stated interest.

red_flags.name: Essay Sounds Adult-Written
red_flags.description: Writing style, vocabulary, or perspective suggests parent or counselor wrote the essay
detection_signals: Vocabulary beyond typical high school level
References or perspectives unusual for a teenager
Overly polished writing lacking teenage authenticity
Voice is inconsistent with other application materials
red_flags.counselor_explanation: This essay doesn't sound like a 17-year-old wrote it. Admissions officers read thousands of essays and can spot adult intervention immediately. This is one of the most damaging things that can happen to an application - it suggests inauthenticity and raises questions about the entire file.

red_flags.name: Clearly Inflated or Exaggerated Achievements
red_flags.description: Claims that seem implausible or aren't verifiable
detection_signals: Founded nonprofit that 'served thousands'
Claims of impact that seem disproportionate to role
Activities that can't be verified
red_flags.counselor_explanation: Some claims in this application raise credibility concerns. Admissions officers are experienced at spotting inflation - and they verify what they can. Exaggeration, if detected, can sink an entire application.

red_flags.name: Avoided Course Rigor When Available
red_flags.description: Took easier courses when more challenging options existed
detection_signals: High grades but few AP/IB/Honors courses
Dropped down from advanced tracks
Doesn't challenge themselves academically
red_flags.counselor_explanation: Your grades are good, but your course selection suggests you're taking the easy path. Selective colleges want to see you challenge yourself academically. A 3.7 in the most rigorous curriculum is more impressive than a 4.0 in standard classes.

the_entrepreneur.risk: Claims must be verifiable and substantial

characteristics: Achievement is more impressive given context
